headline.print_headline: Hard Lesson in Sleep for Teenagers
headline.main: Hard Lesson in Sleep for Teenagers

docs.abstract: Adolescents who do not receive adequate rest have trouble keeping up in the classroom and are more vulnerable to other health problems. And catching up on sleep on the weekend won’t help.
docs.snippet: Adolescents who do not receive adequate rest have trouble keeping up in the classroom and are more vulnerable to other health problems. And catching up on sleep on the weekend won’t help.

headline.print_headline: Has Sugar Lost Its Sweet Spot? Paraguayan Plant Upends Market
headline.main: Has Sugar Lost Its Sweet Spot? Paraguayan Plant Upends Market

docs.lead_paragraph: The maker of America's top sugar brand Domino Sugar is launching its first no-calorie "natural" sweetener extracted from the stevia plant in Paraguay, the strongest sign yet that the upstart product is threatening to eat into raw-sugar demand.
docs.snippet: The maker of America's top sugar brand Domino Sugar is launching its first no-calorie "natural" sweetener extracted from the stevia plant in Paraguay, the strongest sign yet that the upstart product is threatening to eat into raw-sugar demand.

headline.seo: To Battle Sugar, Mayor Bill de Blasio Doesn’t Need a Big-Soda Ban

docs.abstract: Editorial discourages Mayor Bill de Blasio from pursuing ban on large sugary drinks in New York City; argues it is an ineffective way to address obesity problem; suggests de Blasio commit funds to public education programs instead, citing success of anti-soda advertisements.
docs.lead_paragraph: Instead of reviving the big-cup ban, the mayor should encourage New Yorkers to make healthier choices.
docs.snippet: Instead of reviving the big-cup ban, the mayor should encourage New Yorkers to make healthier choices.

headline.print_headline: C.D.C. Director Becomes Face of Nation’s Worry and Flawed Response
headline.main: C.D.C. Director Becomes Face of Nation’s Worry and Flawed Response

byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear, Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Jonathan Martin contributed reporting from Washington.

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas R Frieden, director of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and nation’s top public health official, has become face of Obama administration's flawed response to Ebola in United States; Frieden is likely to face withering questions about his record during a congressional hearing.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the nation’s top public health official, will probably face withering questions about his record during a congressional hearing.
docs.snippet: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the nation’s top public health official, will probably face withering questions about his record during a congressional hearing.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: COWLEY--Geoffrey, 59, died of colon cancer on October 14, 2014. Geoff was a gentle, humble man with a shining intellect and an open heart. Throughout his 30-year career as a journalist and public health advocate, he made science and medicine vividly accessible to general readers, while championing health as a human right. As Newsweek magazine's health editor--a post he held from 1988 through 2006--he exhibited a special talent for simplifying complexity without sacrificing nuance. Whether he was explaining how memory works or reporting on health conditions in the world's poorest countries, he transformed facts into stories as engaging as they were learned. Later, as an associate New York City health commissioner, he helped the Bloomberg administration confront challenges ranging from HIV to smoking and obesity. More recently, as a national writer for msnbc.com, he deftly chronicled the long struggle to implement the Affordable Care Act. To Susan Pelzer, his wife of 30 years, Geoff was the light of the universe gathered in a lifetime. And to Colin Cowley, his 25-year-old son, Geoff was a loving friend and mentor, who consistently emphasized the value of curiosity and compassion. Geoff is survived by many family members who live in the west: his father, James Philip Cowley, his sister, Linda Clark, and her three daughters, his brother, Collin Cowley, and his three children, and the Jorgensen family. Geoff's family requests that any gifts in his honor be made to Doctors Without Borders.
